Students develop specific, practical ways of improving their writing through sustained critical thinking about diverse issues from multiple points of view. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 1.
72829.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and C1 requirements.

72830.desc: Explores, via cross-cultural readings, the nature, uses, and abuses of language. Course work includes extensive writing, both take-home and in-class. Emphasis on revising for power of expression and for variety and accuracy at the sentence level. Enrollment restricted to students who have not passed the Entry Level Writing Requirement. Open to others by permission of instructor.

72831.desc: Explores, via cross-cultural readings, the nature, uses, and abuses of language. Course work includes extensive writing, both take-home and in-class. Emphasis on revising for power of expression and for variety and accuracy at the sentence level. Enrollment restricted to students who have not passed the Entry Level Writing Requirement. Open to others by permission of instructor.

72832.desc: Explores, via cross-cultural readings, the nature, uses, and abuses of language. Course work includes extensive writing, both take-home and in-class. Emphasis on revising for power of expression and for variety and accuracy at the sentence level. Enrollment restricted to students who have not passed the Entry Level Writing Requirement. Open to others by permission of instructor.

72835.desc: The history of the world from 1750. Focuses on the liberal project (the industrial and democratic revolutions) and its impact on the worldslavery and abolition, self-strengthening movements, race and class, imperialism, colonialism, and nationalism.

72836.desc: Explores the political, social, economic, and cultural development of British North America from the first stirrings of resistance to the establishment of the U.S. Course 110A is not a prerequisite to course 110B.

72837.desc: Speaking, listening comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals. Taught entirely in Spanish; conversational fluency is encouraged through classroom practice and conversation groups, and is supplemented by language laboratory work. Classes are held three days a week; students complete the conversation group work independently of the classroom sessions.
72837.re: course 1 or Spanish Placement Examination score of 20.

72838.desc: An introduction to the principles and practices of laboratory microbiology, with a substantial presentation of optical microscopy. Students are billed a materials fee.
72838.re: previous or concurrent enrollment in BIOL 119 is required; satisfaction of Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72839.desc: An introduction to the principles and practices of laboratory microbiology, with a substantial presentation of optical microscopy. Students are billed a materials fee.
72839.re: previous or concurrent enrollment in BIOL 119 is required; satisfaction of Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72840.desc: Covers the structure, organization, and function of eukaryotic cells. Topics include biological membranes, organelles, protein and vesicular trafficking, cellular interactions, the cytoskeleton, and signal transduction. Requires a good understanding of basic biochemistry and molecular biology.
72840.re: BIOL 100 or BIOC 100A. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72841.desc: Topics in morphology, physiology, development, genetics, and endocrinology selected to exemplify current issues and perspectives in organismic biology.
72841.re: BIOL 20A. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 20A. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72842.desc: Introduction to (semiconductor) electronic devices. Conduction of electric currents in semiconductors, the semiconductor p-n junction, the transistor. Analysis and synthesis of linear and nonlinear electronic circuits containing diodes and transistors. Biasing, small signal models, frequency response, and feedback. Operational amplifiers and integrated circuits.
72842.re: course 101/L; previous or concurrent enrollment in course 171L required. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72843.desc: Introduces all students, regardless of experience, to the plays and theater of Shakespeare, and directly addresses linked relevance to contemporary 21st century American culture.

72846.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to oceanography focusing on biological, chemical, geological, and physical processes. Covers topics such as origins and structure of planet Earth and its oceans, co-evolution of Earth and life, plate tectonics, liquid water and the hydrologic and hydrothermal cycles, salinity and elemental cycles, ocean circulation, primary production and nutrient cycles, plankton and nekton, life on the sea floor, near shore and estuarine communities, future environmental problems our oceans face. Students may also enroll in and receive credit for Earth Sciences 1. (Note: General Education credit will not be granted for this course and Biology 80D.)

72847.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 171. One two-hour laboratory session per week. Students are billed a materials fee.
72847.re: courses 101/L; previous or concurrent enrollment in course 171 required. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72848.desc: Introduces fieldwork methods and problems in medical anthropology. Students spend six weeks conducting field work through volunteer activities with local health organizations, and prepare a final ethnographic paper.

72849.desc: Introduces water-based screen printing. Students are introduced to processes including basic equipment, printing techniques, printing papers, stenciling processes, and photographic and digital techniques. Emphasis is on continued development of content and aesthetic awareness through the possibilities of screen printing. May be repeated for credit.

72850.desc: An introduction to the study of ethnic literatures, addressing issues of voice, political agency, and the construction of subjectivity across racial, ethnic, and cultural boundaries in the U.S. Topic: Slavery and the literary imagination.

72851.desc: A selective examination of major writings since WWII, with attention to both literary issues and historical context. Satisfies the English and Modern Literature concentrations. May be repeated for credit.

72852.desc: Topic: Un-taming the shrew--feminism and Shakespearean comedy. Satisfies the English and Pre- and Early Modern Studies Literature concentrations; also satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern distribution requirement. May be repeated for credit.

72853.desc: Comparative examination of fiction in the modern world and of fictional responses to social change and crisis. Topic: comparative American short stories. Satisfies the Modern and World Literature concentrations; also satisfies the Global distribution requirement. May be repeated for credit.

72854.desc: The evolution, taxonomy, physiology, behavior, ecology, and management of birds. Lecture, discussion, field format. Birds observed in habitats including bay, marsh, meadow, and forest. Evaluations based on a field journal and examinations.
72854.re: Courses 105 or Biology 138 are recommended. Enrollment restricted to junior and senior students.

72855.desc: A brief description of the relevant chemical and physical properties of the main classes of foods, vitamins, and minerals. Discussion of their digestion, sources, metabolism, recommended daily allowances, and effects of deficiencies. High school chemistry strongly recommended as preparation.

72856.desc: Explores the sources and context of Beat writing, emphasizing the Beats' intense interest in and engagement with the world at large. Includes works by major and minor Beat writers. Satisfies the English and Modern Literary Studies concentration; also satisfies the Poetry distribution requirement. (Formerly  "Contemporary American Poetry: From Beat to Postlanguage.")

72857.desc: For students interested in becoming better writers, speakers, and communicators about visual art in general and their own work in particular. Provides practice and discussion for arts students as they face situations requiring clear and critical skills for written and spoken expression.
72857.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72858.desc: Focuses on the historical development of what we broadly consider to be the human body from its Humanist instantiations in early modern Europe as seen through its alleged opposite: the monstrous body. Satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern studies concentration; also satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern studies distribution requirement.

72859.desc: Introduction to linguistics through studying the structure and culture of American Sign Language (ASL). Topics include: syntax; morphology and phonology of ASL; deaf culture; language policy; variety in signed languages and ASL literature. No prior knowledge of ASL or linguistics required.

72860.desc: Explores how women artists intervene in the art world by representing themselves and their own work. Their projects and this course engage a range of critical debates about subjectivity, feminism, narrative, and representation. Seminar participants study visual and textual genres, such as women's self-portraiture, performance art, artist statements, visual-textual hybrid projects, scholarly texts by feminist critics, and more.

72861.desc: Style matters; it is powerful and always changing. Organized around a series of "Style Wars" that offer the chance to think about how and why "style" is repeatedly used to ignite social, and not "simply aesthetic," change.

72862.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 171. One two-hour laboratory session per week. Students are billed a materials fee.
72862.re: courses 101/L; previous or concurrent enrollment in course 171 required.

72863.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 171. One two-hour laboratory session per week. Students are billed a materials fee.
72863.re: courses 101/L; previous or concurrent enrollment in course 171 required.

72864.desc: Explores the concept of nihilism in the contemporary Western world and its relation to what might be considered a technological mindset in terms of a Nietzschean and Heideggerian interpretation. Students work through readings as well as relevant films because it may well be argued that contemporary cinema is a metaphorical mirror for our conception both of how the Western world is and how we imagine it should or might be.

72865.desc: By reading the great philosophers of the times, students receive an introduction to philosophical writing on suffering, a foundation in the traditional treatment of suffering, and an assessment of traditional accounts of suffering.

72866.desc: Explores the philosophy of film through the viewing and discussion of several philosophically interesting films. Examines both the aesthetics of film and a variety of philosophical issues that particular films raise.

72867.desc: Focuses on providing practical experience in all phases of exhibition design and implementation. General tasks of program operation supplemented with selective reading and written assignments designed to enhance theoretical understanding of broader issues in art administration. Includes field trips to galleries and museums as well as in-class visits by artists and arts professionals. (Formerly
72867.re: Enrollment restricted to art, pre-art, and history of art and visual culture majors.

72877.desc: Using a transnational perspective,course interrogates the politics of producing cultural memory by analyzing multiple sites (memorials, monuments, oral histories, archives, museums, and art) that aid in the production of cultural memory by assigning meaning to the past. Examines the distinct ways in which the body is raced, gendered, and sexed thereby affecting what we remember and how we remember it. Explores questions of location, power, belonging, identity, race, gender, class, and sexuality through the lens of cultural memory.

72878.desc: Explores the politics of technology and the politics of storytelling by engaging with the histories of everyday technologies. Case studies include the QWERTY keyboard, the standard indoor temperature (72F), electronic hums, and the design of light bulbs.

72879.desc: Provides a clearer understanding of what technology is how it relates to knowledge and human life. Students read and discuss texts by Plato, Aristotle, Husserl, and Heidegger.

72880.desc: Surveys the historical genre and analyzes its relationship to social justice movements. Students examine the role of the documentary in highlighting people's history, culminating in the production of their own historical documentaries.

72881.desc: Offered in summer. Provides a theoretical and practical foundation for teaching reading within content area instruction in middle school and secondary classrooms.  Field experiences and interactive instruction will facilitate learning about strategies, curricula, methods, materials, and observation. Intended for students pursuing a single subject credential.

72882.desc: Computer-based laboratory course in which students gain hands-on experience in analysis of data sets arising from statistical problem-solving in the biological, environmental, and health sciences. Descriptive methods, interval estimation, hypothesis testing, one-and two-sample problems, correlation and regression, one-way analysis of variance, categorical data analysis. (Formerly
72882.re: score of 31 or higher on mathematics placement exam, course 2 or 3 or 11A or Mathematics 3 or 11A or 19A or by permission of instructor.  Concurrent enrollment in course 7 is required.

72883.desc: Laboratory sequence in assembly language programming. The basics of logic design, both RISC and microcontroller programming. May include C language programming. Two two-hour laboratories per week .
72883.re: course 3 or 8, or Computer Science 10 or 12A  or 5C or 5J or 5P, or Biomolecular Engineering 60, or suitable programming experience; previous or concurrent enrollment in course 12 required.

72884.desc: Explores Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop as they relate to science illustration. Includes current illustration techniques covering  the integration of the digital medium into a traditional artist's workflow using natural subjects illustrated to science illustration standards. No prior Adobe Illustrator or Photoshop experience necessary.

72885.desc: Hands-on introduction to computer music. Students encounter a broad spectrum of technologies drawn from the history of electroacoustic music and apply them through regular programming/composition assignments. No previous experience with computer programming is assumed.

72886.desc: For students interested in becoming better writers, speakers, and communicators about visual art in general and their own work in particular. Provides practice and discussion for arts students as they face situations requiring clear and critical skills for written and spoken expression.
72886.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

72887.desc: Introduction to photography as an art form that explores visual ideas beginning with camera-ready use, negative development, and printing. Prepares for further work in photography or for collaboration with other media in art including computer arts and two- and three-dimensional mixed media. Critically examines photographic works while reading historical and theoretical texts. Students are billed  a materials fee.
72887.re: Enrollment restricted to pre-art and history of art and visual culture majors.

72889.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 6A. One three-hour laboratory session per week.

72890.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 6C. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
72890.re: courses 6A/L or 5A/L; concurrent enrollment in course 6C required; courses 6B/M are suggested.

72893.desc: Computer-based laboratory course in which students gain hands-on experience in analysis of data sets arising from statistical problem-solving in the biological, environmental, and health sciences. Descriptive methods, interval estimation, hypothesis testing, one-and two-sample problems, correlation and regression, one-way analysis of variance, categorical data analysis. (Formerly
72893.re: score of 31 or higher on mathematics placement exam, course 2 or 3 or 11A or Mathematics 3 or 11A or 19A or by permission of instructor.  Concurrent enrollment in course 7 is required.

72894.desc: Fundamentals of music and notation. Major, minor scales, intervals, triads, and inversions, root-position 7th chords, and the beginning harmonic analysis. Emphasis on the development of the ear and coordination. Exercises of pulse, rhythm, pitch, and coordination. Dictation and sight singing.
72894.re: Enrollment restricted to first-year students and sophomores; juniors and seniors admitted by permission of instructor.

72895.desc: Continuation of course 13. Triads and 7th chords and  their inversions. Introduces Church modes, melodic and harmonic analysis, four-part harmony, and keyboard harmony. Sight-singing, ear training, and dictation. Knowledge of musical notation and scales required. Students who wish to take this course and have not taken course 13 or the placement exam should consult the instructor. See the enrollment conditions section of the quarterly
72895.re: course 13 or music core curriculum placement exam. Enrollment priority given to students for whom course 14 or 30A is a requirement.

72996.desc: Independent study and research under faculty supervision. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

72997.desc: Thesis research conducted under faculty supervision. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency.
